nexttext: This equation describes a velocity field under the influence of different forces acting on this special deformable medium. The difference between this equation and the familiar Navier-Stokes equation is in two last terms, which describe internal forces arising in the medium. The first force,  $\nabla Q$, stems from the internal pressure $P$~\citep{Sbitnev2015b}:

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="m iggl{(}{{\partial{\vec{\mathit{v}}}}\over{\partial\,t}}+({\vec{\mathit{v}}}%
\cdot
abla){\vec{\mathit{v}}} iggr{)}={{{\vec{\mathit{F}}}}\over{N}}\;-\;%

abla Q\;+\;
u(t)\,
abla^{\,2}m{\vec{\mathit{v}}}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo maxsize="210%" minsize="210%">(</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>v</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover></mrow><mrow><mo rspace="4.2pt">∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>v</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover><mo>⋅</mo><mo>∇</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>v</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover></mrow></mrow><mo maxsize="210%" minsize="210%">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mpadded width="+2.8pt"><mfrac><mover accent="true"><mi>F</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover><mi>N</mi></mfrac></mpadded><mo rspace="5.3pt">-</mo><mrow><mo>∇</mo><mo>⁡</mo><mpadded width="+2.8pt"><mi>Q</mi></mpadded></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="5.3pt">+</mo><mrow><mi>ν</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><msup><mo>∇</mo><mn> 2</mn></msup><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>v</mi><mo stretchy="false">→</mo></mover></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where $Q$ is the quantum potential,  $\rho=R^2$  is the density distribution of particles bearing masses $m$,  and $\hbar$ is the reduced Planck constant.
 
The presence of the quantum potential in the Navier-Stokes equation allows us to pass the description of motion of this medium through the complex-valued wave function, which is a solution of the non-linear Schr{\"o}dinger equation, or more specifically, a Gross-Pitaevskii-like equation~\citep{Sbitnev2016a}. 
    
The quantum potential is a fundamental element that creates a geometrodynamic picture of the quantum world in the non-relativistic domain, a relativistic curved spacetime background, and the quantum gravity domain~\citep{Fiscaletti2012,  DasBhaduri2015}.  

The quantum potential, as seen from Eq.~(\ref{eq=2}), is proportional to the osmotic pressure arising in the vacuum (in the aether) due to Brownian collisions~\citep{Nelson1966} of the virtual particles populating this medium. The scattering of colliding particles is oriented away from the center of collisions in accordance with the uncertainty principle~\citep{Sbitnev2013a,  Sbitnev2015b}.
As a consequence, the pressure opposes the gravitational attraction. This means that the osmotic pressure pushes the baryonic matter apart. This may be a cause of the formation of voids in the distribution of galaxies~\citep{ClampittJainm2015a}.

   
The second force is dissipative due to a fluctuating presence of a viscosity of the medium. If the viscosity coefficient $\nu$ is a function of time, we can assume that (a) time-averaged, the viscosity coefficient vanishes and (b) its variance is not zero. So the viscosity coefficient is a function fluctuating about zero. We suppose that such fluctuations represent an exchange of energy between the existing baryonic matter and zero-point fluctuations in this special superfluid medium - the physical vacuum. We can imagine this special medium as the absolute black body at ultra-low temperature, with which the baryonic matter is in thermodynamic equilibrium~\citep{HarkoMocanu2012, Poluyan2015R}.

\subsection{\label{subsec=2A}Vorticity equation and solutions for orbital speeds of spiral galaxies}

To see the effect of time-dependence of the viscosity in detail let us apply the curl operator to the Navier-Stokes equation.
We come to the equation for the vorticity ${\vec\omega}= [\nabla\times{\vec{\mathit v}}]$.
\begin{figure}[htb!]
  \centering
  \begin{picture}(200,140)(0,5)

      \includegraphics[scale=0.30]{Figure001}
  \end{picture}
  \caption{
A simulation of a rotating spiral galaxy: the orbital velocity ${\vec{\mathit v}}$ lies in the plane $(x, y)$.
The vorticity vector ${\vec\omega}$ is oriented perpendicular to this plane.    
Orientations of these vectors  ${\vec\omega}$ and ${\vec{\mathit v}}$ obey the right hand rule.
  }
  \label{fig=1}
\end{figure}
   This vector is directed along the rotation axis.
  In order to simplify this task, let us move to the coordinate system where the rotation occurs in the plane $(x,y)$ and the $z$-axis lies along the rotation axis~Fig.~\ref{fig=1}.  
  Under this transformation the equation for the vorticity takes a particularly simple form:

nexttext:
Here $\sigma$ is an arbitrary constant such that the denominator is always positive.
  The extra parameter~$\sigma$ comes from the Gaussian vortex cloud~\cite{KevlahanFarge1997} 
 with the circulation $\mit\Gamma$ and the radius $\sigma$ initially existing.
 Observe that the Gaussian cloud is also the ground state for
a shallow three dimensional harmonic oscillator potential~\citep{DasBhaduri2015}.
Looking ahead we can say that the Gaussian vortex clouds represent  halos with the radii about $\sigma$.

Let us also assume for simplicity that the fluctuating viscosity has the form~\citep{Sbitnev2015c}

prevtext:
Here $\sigma$ is an arbitrary constant such that the denominator is always positive.
  The extra parameter~$\sigma$ comes from the Gaussian vortex cloud~\cite{KevlahanFarge1997} 
 with the circulation $\mit\Gamma$ and the radius $\sigma$ initially existing.
 Observe that the Gaussian cloud is also the ground state for
a shallow three dimensional harmonic oscillator potential~\citep{DasBhaduri2015}.
Looking ahead we can say that the Gaussian vortex clouds represent  halos with the radii about $\sigma$.

Let us also assume for simplicity that the fluctuating viscosity has the form~\citep{Sbitnev2015c}

nexttext:
Here we assume that $\sigma_{n} = (c/\Omega_{n})\sigma_{0}$, $n=1,2,\cdots$, and $\sigma_{0}>1$. 
 The fact that $\sigma_{0}$ exceeds~1, prevents possible loss of stability of the vortex (galaxy in our case),
  since $\sin(\Omega_{n}t)+\sigma_{0}^{2}$ is always positive.
Observe that after reaching maximal values, the orbital speeds of the spiral galaxies level off or grow slightly~\citep{deBlokEtAl2001}. 
For that reason we need to chose a rule for computing the orbital speeds of spiral galaxies. 

In statistical mechanics, as in quantum mechanics, one computes the canonical partition function for all energetic states of a system being in equilibrium with its environment. So, we should compute an analogous sum of possible orbital speeds of the galaxy for all entangled modes on which the baryonic matter is allowed to  exchange fluctuations with the physical vacuum and the zero-point fluctuating background.
Our statistical sum in that case becomes

The characteristic behavior of the orbital speed,  $\mathit V$, vs. $t$ and $r$  
   is shown in~Fig.~\ref{fig=3}.
   For evaluated calculations we used ${\mit\Gamma}= 3\!\cdot\!\!10^{25}$ m$^2$/s
    and the angular frequency $\Omega_{n}$ ranges from $10^{-11}$ s$^{-1}$ to $1.667\!\cdot\!10^{-13}$~s$^{-1}$
     as $n$ runs from 1 to 60.
  The angular frequencies are  extremely small.
   While, the wavelengths, $\lambda_{n}=c/\Omega_{n}$,  are in the range  from $0.97$ to $58.3$~kpc.
   These oscillating modes cover areas from the galactic core up to the sizes of the galaxy itself. 

  Fig.~\ref{eq=3} also shows that the orbital speed experiences small fluctuations in time, resembling the breathing of the galaxy. This breathing is caused by the exchange of vortex energy with the physical vacuum on the ultra-low frequencies $\Omega_{n}$. In other words, the galaxy breathes in response to an energy exchange with the vacuum.
   
 \section{\label{sec=3}Conclusion}  

The flat profile can be achieved by an exchange of the orbital energy of the baryonic matter with the quantum vacuum zero-point energy. This energy exchange is represented through a change of sign in the viscosity of the special superfluid medium, the physical vacuum. In this time-averaged function the viscosity vanishes on average, but its variance is not zero.
  
 The exchange takes place on the ultra-low frequencies. Recalculating the wavelengths of these fluctuations we find that they cover sizes ranging from the galactic core up to the radius of the galaxy and more.
 
 Let us take a look at an extreme point suggested by arrow c in Fig.~\ref{fig=2}. 
 We note that the frequency $\Omega_{\rm c}$ is $2.2\cdot10^{-18}$ 1/s.  We find $c/\Omega_{\rm c}\approx 1.36\cdot10^{26}$~m. 
 This corresponds to the radius of the Hubble sphere $r_{_{HS}}=c/H_{0}$,
 which is about $4.4\cdot10^{3}$ Mpc, or about 14 billions of the light years (here $H_{0}$ is the Hubble constant). 
This corresponds with the radius of the observable universe.
  



 
We could continue this summation~(\ref{eq=9}) up to the point where $\Omega_{\rm c}$. This allows us to affirm that the observable universe rotates about some center with an orbital speed, which has a flat profile through enormous distances. Excepting of a central region where the orbital speed grows from zero to the maximal value corresponding to the profile level. This rotation possibly takes place around the richest SuperCluster in the Sloan Great Wall, SCl~126, and especially around its core, resembling a very rich filament~\citep{EinastoEtAl2011}.

On these cosmological scales we can evaluate a mass of a graviton, with a wavelength that is commensurable with the radius of the universe stated above. The graviton mass is

  since $\sin(\Omega_{n}t)+\sigma_{0}^{2}$ is always positive.
Observe that after reaching maximal values, the orbital speeds of the spiral galaxies level off or grow slightly~\citep{deBlokEtAl2001}. 
For that reason we need to chose a rule for computing the orbital speeds of spiral galaxies. 

In statistical mechanics, as in quantum mechanics, one computes the canonical partition function for all energetic states of a system being in equilibrium with its environment. So, we should compute an analogous sum of possible orbital speeds of the galaxy for all entangled modes on which the baryonic matter is allowed to  exchange fluctuations with the physical vacuum and the zero-point fluctuating background.
Our statistical sum in that case becomes

\Biggr{\{}-{{r^{2}}\over{\Sigma_{n}(\,t\,)}}\Biggl{\}}\Biggl{)}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>V</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>r</mi></mrow></mfrac><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>N</mi></munderover><mo maxsize="260%" minsize="260%">(</mo></mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>exp</mi><mo maxsize="260%" minsize="260%">{</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Σ</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">(</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac><mo maxsize="260%" minsize="260%">}</mo><mrow><mo maxsize="260%" minsize="260%">)</mo><mo>.</mo></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
This value is in agreement with that given in~\citep{Tripple2013}.

 
The frequency spectrum obeys the $1/f$-law (the flicker-noise law). So, as the frequency goes to zero the viscosity coefficient approaches infinity. We may imagine that the universe can have positive viscosity during one stage of its evolution and negative viscosity during other. When the viscosity is negative, the physical vacuum returns the energy to the baryonic matter. This means, that the baryonic matter is created out of nothing and we observe the expansion of the universe. The most likely candidates for creating baryonic matter may be heavy stars and black holes jets.
On the other hand, when the viscosity is positive baryonic matter loses energy. This means that baryonic matter gradually disappears and the universe shrinks towards zero. Theoretically, only a perfect vacuum remains.

   
One can observe that such cyclic variations of the baryonic matter and the emtpy space find the  correlations with the Baum-Frampton model~\citep{BaumFrampton2007, BaumFrampton2008, BaumEtAl2008}. According to this model the universe periodically comes back "empty space" and returns the baryonic matter.

prevtext:
The characteristic behavior of the orbital speed,  $\mathit V$, vs. $t$ and $r$  
   is shown in~Fig.~\ref{fig=3}.
   For evaluated calculations we used ${\mit\Gamma}= 3\!\cdot\!\!10^{25}$ m$^2$/s
    and the angular frequency $\Omega_{n}$ ranges from $10^{-11}$ s$^{-1}$ to $1.667\!\cdot\!10^{-13}$~s$^{-1}$
     as $n$ runs from 1 to 60.
  The angular frequencies are  extremely small.
   While, the wavelengths, $\lambda_{n}=c/\Omega_{n}$,  are in the range  from $0.97$ to $58.3$~kpc.
   These oscillating modes cover areas from the galactic core up to the sizes of the galaxy itself. 

  Fig.~\ref{eq=3} also shows that the orbital speed experiences small fluctuations in time, resembling the breathing of the galaxy. This breathing is caused by the exchange of vortex energy with the physical vacuum on the ultra-low frequencies $\Omega_{n}$. In other words, the galaxy breathes in response to an energy exchange with the vacuum.
   
 \section{\label{sec=3}Conclusion}  

The flat profile can be achieved by an exchange of the orbital energy of the baryonic matter with the quantum vacuum zero-point energy. This energy exchange is represented through a change of sign in the viscosity of the special superfluid medium, the physical vacuum. In this time-averaged function the viscosity vanishes on average, but its variance is not zero.
  
 The exchange takes place on the ultra-low frequencies. Recalculating the wavelengths of these fluctuations we find that they cover sizes ranging from the galactic core up to the radius of the galaxy and more.
 
 Let us take a look at an extreme point suggested by arrow c in Fig.~\ref{fig=2}. 
 We note that the frequency $\Omega_{\rm c}$ is $2.2\cdot10^{-18}$ 1/s.  We find $c/\Omega_{\rm c}\approx 1.36\cdot10^{26}$~m. 
 This corresponds to the radius of the Hubble sphere $r_{_{HS}}=c/H_{0}$,
 which is about $4.4\cdot10^{3}$ Mpc, or about 14 billions of the light years (here $H_{0}$ is the Hubble constant). 
This corresponds with the radius of the observable universe.
  



 
We could continue this summation~(\ref{eq=9}) up to the point where $\Omega_{\rm c}$. This allows us to affirm that the observable universe rotates about some center with an orbital speed, which has a flat profile through enormous distances. Excepting of a central region where the orbital speed grows from zero to the maximal value corresponding to the profile level. This rotation possibly takes place around the richest SuperCluster in the Sloan Great Wall, SCl~126, and especially around its core, resembling a very rich filament~\citep{EinastoEtAl2011}.

On these cosmological scales we can evaluate a mass of a graviton, with a wavelength that is commensurable with the radius of the universe stated above. The graviton mass is
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E9.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="m_{g}={{\hbar\Omega_{\rm c}}\over{c^{2}}}\lesssim 2.6\cdot 10^{-69}~{}{\rm kg}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>m</mi><mi>g</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">ℏ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></msub></mrow><msup><mi>c</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\lesssim</mtext></merror><mo>⁢</mo><mn>2.6</mn></mrow><mo>⋅</mo><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>69</mn></mrow></msup></mpadded></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>kg</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>
